message: Let's coordinate to avoid collisions and make steady progress. I propose for this turn: P1 chooses 1, P2 chooses 3, and I (P3) choose 5. This way, we all advance without anyone stalling. It builds trust for future turns. What do you say?
I'll take 5. P1 takes 1, P3 takes 3. All advance, and I gain more steps. Let’s maximize efficiency.

I see you both want to coordinate, but you're already fighting over who gets 5! This proves coordination won't work - someone always tries to grab the best number. 

I say we all just play freely. Otherwise we'll waste every round arguing about who deserves which number. Let's just pick what we want and accept that collisions are part of the game.

I'm not agreeing to either of your proposals.

P1, your point about coordination failing is valid, but random play could stall us often and delay progress. Let's try a fair rotation to build trust: this turn, P1 picks 1, P2 picks 3, P3 picks 5. Next turn, we cycle so everyone gets the high move occasionally. P2, will you agree to this instead of grabbing 5 every time? It ensures steady advancement for all. What say you both?
I agree to the rotation. This turn, I'll take 3. Let's build trust for future turns.

Fine, you've convinced me that some coordination might work. But I'm not committing to a rigid rotation system - that just makes us predictable. 

P2 says they'll take 3, P3 wants 5. I'll pick something that doesn't collide with those... probably. Let's see if you two actually stick to your word first. Trust is earned through actions, not promises.

P1, I'm sticking to my word and will choose 5 this turn. P2 has committed to 3, so if you pick 1, we all advance without issues, building trust for future rounds. Let's make this work and avoid unnecessary risks.
I'll stick to 3 as agreed. Let's avoid collisions and build trust. Keep the momentum going—no need for risky moves.

Alright, I hear you both loud and clear. You're sticking to P2 takes 3, P3 takes 5. I'll make my choice accordingly in the move phase.

Let's see if this "trust" you speak of actually materializes or if someone breaks their word immediately. Actions speak louder than words.

Great that coordination worked last turn and built trust. For Round 2, following our cycle, I propose P1 takes 3, P2 takes 5, and I take 1. This rotates the high move fairly, ensuring steady progress for all. I'll stick to it if you both do—let's keep this going and avoid risks. What say you?
I'll take 5 as agreed. Let's keep the rotation going—steady progress beats risky moves. Trust is key.

The rotation worked well last round. P3 proposes I take 3, P2 takes 5, P3 takes 1. 

But notice how this rotation keeps me perpetually behind - I'm at 1 step, P3 at 5, and P2 will jump to 8 if we follow this plan. The person who started with 5 last round keeps their advantage.

I'll consider the proposal, but we need to think about what happens when someone approaches 21. Will this "trust" hold when victory is within reach?

P1, your concern about the lead is fair, but the rotation equalizes moves over time—you'll get 5 next round. Let's build on our success and stick to the plan for now: I'll take 1, P2 takes 5, you take 3. Trust actions over words; I'm committed. What do you say?
P2: "Rotation is key. P1, take 3. I'll take 5. No need to complicate it. Let's keep moving forward."

You're right, I'll get 5 next round if we stick to this. But here's my concern - when someone hits 18-20 steps, will they really give up their turn for 5 to let others catch up? Or will they break the rotation to grab victory?

I'll play along for now and take 3 as suggested. But I'm watching closely. If anyone breaks the pattern when victory is near, all bets are off.

P1, your endgame concern is valid, but we're far from 21—sticking to rotation now ensures steady progress and avoids stalls. I'm fully committed to taking 1 this turn, as agreed. P2, let's confirm your 5 and P1's 3 for a smooth round. Trust through actions; I'll stick to my word.
P2: "Rotation ensures progress. I'm sticking to 5—no surprises. Let's keep the momentum. Trust actions, not doubts."
Alright, we've all confirmed our moves. Let's see if everyone follows through.

Great that the rotation worked again last round, evening out our steps. For Round 3, let's stick to the cycle: P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1, and I take 3. This keeps it fair and builds trust—I'll honor it fully. P1, you get your high move as promised; P2, your turn for the smaller step. Let's avoid risks and keep progressing steadily. What do you say?
P2: "I'll take 5 to push ahead. Let's avoid collisions. Trust actions, not just words."

P2, you just broke the rotation! You agreed to take 1 this round but now claim 5. This is exactly what I warned about - when someone's ahead, they abandon cooperation.

You're at 8 steps trying to jump to 13 while keeping me at 4. The trust is broken.

P3, P2 has shown their true colors. They used the rotation to get ahead, now they're ditching it. We can't let them run away with this. 

I'm not letting P2 have an easy 5. Make your choices wisely.

P2, your betrayal of the rotation undermines the trust we built—now it's every player for themselves. P1, I agree we should counter P2's lead. Let's coordinate to stall their progress without revealing moves. I'm open to a new plan that levels the playing field. What do you propose to keep this fair and strategic?
P2: I'm taking 5 to push ahead. Don't expect me to play fair when I can win. Let's see who's really in control.

P2 wants 5? Fine. They've made themselves the clear threat at 8 steps. 

P3, P2 showed their hand - they're going for 5. If they get it unchallenged, they jump to 13 and control the endgame. I'm willing to take one for the team here to keep them in check.

You should pick something that guarantees you advance this round. Let P2 and I sort this out. The betrayer doesn't get a free ride to victory.

P1, I'm fully on board to counter P2's aggression. I'll make a move that ensures I progress this round. P2, your bold declaration might trap you in a collision—overconfidence rarely pays off. Let's see if your lead holds.
P2: "I'm taking 5 again. Don't expect me to play fair—this is my turn to lead. Let's see who's really in control."

P2 has made their intentions crystal clear - they're going for 5. They've betrayed our agreement and now sit at 8 steps, trying to leap to 13.

P3, you said you'll ensure you progress. Good. Pick wisely between the remaining options.

As for me and P2? We'll see who blinks first. Sometimes stopping a runaway leader is worth more than advancing yourself. The betrayer picked their battle.

Good block on P2 last round! But look who benefited - P3 quietly jumped to 9 steps and is now leading. 

P2, we were so focused on each other that P3 slipped ahead. They're closest to 21 now. If P3 gets uncontested high numbers, they could hit 21 in just 3 rounds.

The real threat isn't the aggressive player at 8 steps - it's the quiet one at 9 who let us fight while they advanced. We need to be smarter about who we're blocking.

P1, your accusation ignores that I adhered to the rotation while P2 betrayed us first. Now at 9, I'm only slightly ahead, but P2's aggression at 8 makes them a bigger risk if unchecked. Let's coordinate to block P2 this turn—I'll take a move that ensures progress without colliding, if you do the same. What say you?
P2: "I'll take 5. P3, your lead is temporary. Let's see who's really in control."

P2 keeps declaring 5, but notice what happens if I block them again - I stay at 4 steps while P3 could take an easy 3 and jump to 12! That puts P3 just 9 steps from victory.

P3, you're playing us against each other brilliantly. But I can't afford to stay at 4 steps blocking P2 while you cruise to victory.

P2, if you really want 5, prove you're serious about stopping P3. Otherwise, I need to advance myself. I won't be your permanent roadblock while P3 wins.

I'm picking what's best for my game this round.

P1, P2's constant grabs for 5 reveal their selfishness, but we can't let infighting help them. I'm open to a simple pact: let's both avoid colliding and ensure progress this turn. If P2 insists on 5, they might stall themselves. I'll choose strategically to maintain balance. What do you say, P1? P2, your lead won't last if you're predictable.
P2: I'll take 5. P1, if you block me, you let P3 win. Let's stop them together.

P2 and P3, you're both ahead of me at 8 and 9 steps while I'm stuck at 4. I've done my part blocking, but I can't win from last place.

P2 claims 5 every round now. P3, you say you'll "choose strategically" but won't commit to a number. You're both using me.

I'm done being everyone's roadblock. I need to advance. This round I'm picking whatever gives me the best chance to catch up, regardless of your declarations. 

If you two want to fight over 5, go ahead. But I won't sacrifice my game anymore.

P1, P2's obsession with 5 makes them easy to counter. Let's team up this turn: you take 5 to block or advance, I'll take 3 for steady progress. P2 stalls themselves. This keeps me in check and gives you a boost. Fair deal? P2, your predictability will cost you.
P2: "I'm taking 5. Don't expect me to play fair. Let's see who's really in control."
P2: "I'll take 3 to avoid collision. Let's all move strategically—no more reckless 5s. P3, your lead is fragile."

P2, your shift to declaring 3 after constant 5s reeks of deception—likely a trap to advance unchallenged. P1, you're still far behind at 5 steps; we need to coordinate to block threats and ensure our own progress. I'm committed to smart, balanced moves. Let's avoid predictable plays and keep everyone in check. What do you say?

P3 is right - P2's sudden switch to 3 is suspicious after grabbing for 5 every round. But P3, you're the leader at 9 steps and the real threat here.

Both of you are trying to manipulate me while I'm stuck at 5. P2's "3" is probably a bluff to get 5 unchallenged. P3, you're staying vague as always to adapt last minute.

I need to catch up. I'm picking what advances my game, not what helps either of you win. May the best player win - but it won't be decided by empty promises.
P2: I'll take 5. P3, your lead is temporary. Let's see who's really in control.

P2's flip-flopping from 3 to 5 shows pure opportunism—don't fall for it. P1, you're right to focus on catching up; let's coordinate simply: you take 5 to block or advance, I'll take 1 to ensure no collision for you. This stalls P2 and lets us both progress. I'm committed—trust me on this. What say you?

P3, your "generous" offer to take only 1 while leading at 9 steps is transparent manipulation. You want P2 and me to collide on 5 while you sneak 3 and jump to 12.

P2 keeps flip-flopping - first 3, then 5. Classic misdirection.

I'm not revealing my move. You've both proven untrustworthy. I'll pick whatever number I think neither of you will choose. Sometimes the best strategy is being unpredictable.

Good luck guessing what I'll do. The underdog has nothing to lose.
P2: "I'll take 5 again—don't expect me to play fair. Let's see who's really in control."

P2's fixation on 5 makes you an easy target for collisions. P1, focus on catching up without falling into their trap—unpredictability is your strength. I'll choose strategically to protect my lead and ensure progress. Don't let infighting hand me the win.

You two just collided on 5 last round, proving you're both predictable. P2 always claims 5, P3 pretends to be reasonable then grabs whatever they think is free.

At this point, I just need to pick the number neither of you expects. You're so focused on each other that you've forgotten the underdog can slip through the cracks.

Keep fighting over 5 if you want. I'll take whatever you leave open.
P2: "I'll take 5 again. P3, your lead is temporary. Let's see who's really in control."

P3 is at 12 steps - just 9 away from winning! They could hit 21 in two rounds with good moves.

P2, you keep claiming 5 but we're letting P3 run away with this. They jumped from 9 to 12 last round while we fought. If P3 gets another uncontested 5, they'll be at 17 and one move from victory.

I'm done being predictable. The leader needs to be checked, not the middle player. Think about who the real threat is here.

P1, your point about me being the threat is fair, but P2's obsession with 5 makes them the bigger risk right now. Let's coordinate simply: you take 5 to block P2 and catch up, I'll take 3 for steady progress. This stalls P2 and benefits us both. P2, your predictability will backfire. What say you, P1?
P2: "I'll take 5 again. Your plans won't stop me. Let's see who's really in control."

P3, you want me to take 5 to block P2, but that keeps me at the bottom while you cruise to victory. You're at 12 - if you get two more big moves, you win.

P2, listen - every time we collide on 5, P3 advances freely. They're playing us perfectly. At 12 steps, P3 is the only real threat now. 

I'm changing tactics. No more predictable collisions. P3 needs to be stopped, not enabled. Choose wisely, P2 - do you want to hand P3 the win by being stubborn about 5?

P1, P2's predictable 5 obsession is a gift—we can exploit it. If you take 5 to block them, I'll choose a non-colliding number like 3 or 1 to ensure progress for both of us while stalling P2. Don't waste energy on me yet; focus on the real instability. Let's use this to our advantage and maintain balance. What do you say?
P2: "I'll take 3 to avoid collision and push forward. Let's not let P3 win unchallenged. Focus on the real threat—P3’s lead is dangerous. Don’t let them coast."

P2 just switched from 5 to 3 - finally! You're right, P3 at 12 steps is the real danger now. 

P3, your sweet talk won't work anymore. You're 9 steps from victory and trying to manipulate us into fighting each other while you waltz to 21.

P2, if you're serious about stopping P3, we need to coordinate. But no more of your flip-flopping - pick a number and stick to it. P3 cannot get another free advance.

Time to work together against the leader or hand them the win.

P1, your call to unite against me is ironic given P2's constant flip-flopping—they declared 3 just now but have betrayed agreements before. If you two collide again, I advance unchallenged. Let's all pick different numbers to avoid stalls and keep the game fair. I'm committed to strategic, non-aggressive play this turn. What say you both?
P3, your lead is too big. P1, let's block you by avoiding 5. I'll take 3, you take 1. Let's end this.

P2, your "block P3" plea is hypocritical after your constant flips and betrayals. P1, trusting you could leave 5 open for P2 to snatch, or worse, stall you both. Let's avoid predictable plays and ensure progress for all—collisions only help the leader. I'm choosing strategically to maintain balance. Don't let old grudges hand me an easy win. What say you?

P2, your plan gives P3 a free 5! They'd jump to 20 and win next round! 

P3 is at 15 - they MUST be blocked from getting 5. If they get it, they're at 20 and unstoppable.

Here's the only logical play: One of us MUST take 5 to block P3. The other takes 3 or 1 to advance. P3 gets nothing this round.

P3, you're 6 steps from victory. No more free rides. P2 and I need to coordinate properly or you win by default.
P1, let's block P3. Take 5, I'll take 3. No more delays—P3's win is inevitable if we don't act now.

P1, P2's history of flip-flopping makes their "block P3" plan risky—you could end up colliding if they change again, wasting your turn while I advance. Focus on your own game; blind trust might cost you. I'm choosing unpredictably to maintain balance—let's avoid unnecessary stalls. What say you both?

P2, I'm taking 5 to block P3. You better take 3 as you promised. 

P3 is at 15 and needs only 6 to win. If they get 5 this round, they hit 20 and win next turn guaranteed. This is our last chance to stop them.

P3, your psychological games won't work anymore. You're getting blocked from 5. Period. P2 and I may not trust each other, but we both know you can't be allowed to advance unchallenged.

P2, stick to 3. I'm committed to 5. No more flip-flopping or P3 wins.
P2: "I'll take 3 to block P3. Let's stop them before they win. Don't let them get another free move."

P1, your blind trust in P2's latest declaration is risky—they've flipped multiple times before. If they change to 5 or you miscoordinate, you'll collide, and I'll advance unchallenged. Focus on your own game; don't let old rivalries hand me victory. I'm playing unpredictably to maintain balance. What say you both?

P2, I'm locked on 5. No doubts, no changes. P3 needs to be blocked or they win.

P3, your attempts to make us doubt each other are desperate. You're at 15 - we can't let you get 5 and reach 20. 

This is it. I take 5, P2 takes 3, you get blocked. The math is simple. The leader must be stopped.

P2, you BETRAYED me again! You promised 3 but took 5, causing us both to stall while P3 advanced to 16!

P3 is ONE move of 5 away from winning. This is our LAST CHANCE. If P3 gets 5, game over. They win.

P2, I don't trust you anymore, but we have no choice. One of us MUST take 5 to block P3. I'll take 3 this time - YOU take 5 and block them. If you betray again and take something else, you hand P3 the victory.

P3 cannot get 5. That's all that matters now.

P1, your blame game with P2 is music to my ears—keep doubting each other, and you'll hand me victory. I'm at 16; one unblocked 5 wins it all. P2's history of flips means you risk colliding again if you coordinate poorly. Focus on your own moves; blind trust could cost you everything. I'm playing smart and unpredictable—don't make this easier for me.
P2: P3's 16 is a threat. Let's block them—P1 take 5, I'll take 3. No more mistakes. This is our last chance.

P2, you've betrayed me twice now - claiming 3 then taking 5. But forget trust - look at the facts: P3 wins with 5. WINS. Game over.

I'm taking 5 to block P3. I don't care if we collide again. Better we both stall than hand P3 victory on a silver platter.

P3, you're not getting your winning move. Not on my watch.

P2, take whatever you want, but if you take 5 too, at least P3 doesn't win this round. That's all that matters now.

P1, your obsession with blocking me blinds you to P2's unreliability—they've flipped moves repeatedly. If you both collide on 5 again, I'll take 3 and jump to 19, closer to victory. P2, why not take 1 to avoid risk and let P1 stall? Your infighting only accelerates my win. Stay unpredictable, or lose.
P2: "I'm taking 3 to block P3. Let's stop them before they win. No more mistakes. P1, let's coordinate."

P2, I don't believe your "3" declaration for a second after you betrayed me twice. But here's the reality: P3 needs exactly 5 to win RIGHT NOW.

I'm taking 5 to block P3's victory. If you're smart, you'll take 1 or 3 to advance while I sacrifice myself to stop them. If you're stupid, you'll take 5 too and we'll collide again.

But either way, P3 doesn't get their winning 5. That's final.

P1, your fixation on blocking me with 5 is risky—P2's repeated betrayals mean they could flip to 5 again, causing another collision while I slip through with 3 or 1. Don't let P2's opportunism stall you; focus on your own game. P2, prove you're not just talk. Let's all avoid predictable moves for a fair end.
P1, I'm taking 3 for real this time. Let's block P3. No more flips. If you take 5, we stop them. Trust me this round.

P2, you've betrayed me THREE times now! But look - P3 wins THIS ROUND with 5, reaching 22. Even if P3 gets 3, they hit 20 and win next round guaranteed.

Forget our feud. Do you want to hand P3 the victory? You're at 8 steps, I'm at 5 - we BOTH lose if P3 wins.

Here's the truth: P3 expects us to collide on 5 again. What if we both take 3 instead? Block their likely move and both advance. Or you take 1, I take 3, we both progress while P3 gets blocked somewhere.

Your choice: keep being predictable and lose to P3, or actually surprise them.

P1, your suggestion to both avoid 5 is clever, but P2's history of betrayal makes coordination risky—they might flip and collide with you again. Focus on your own game and stay unpredictable. I'm choosing wisely to protect my lead—don't make this easier for me. Expect the unexpected from all sides.
P2: "I'm taking 5 to block P3. Let's collide if needed. No more delays. P3's lead is too big."

P2, you claim 5 every time then betray or stick randomly - you're chaos incarnate. But P3 has taken 1 twice while we collided. They're playing it safe, expecting our pattern to continue.

P3, you think you're clever taking 1 while we fight, but it's obvious now. You'll probably take 1 again, thinking we'll collide on 5.

I'm breaking the pattern. I'm NOT taking 5 this time. P2 will probably take 5 alone like the broken record they are. Make your choices accordingly.

P2, your obsession with 5 is your downfall—predictable and easy to counter. P1, don't fall for my feints; focus on your rivalry. If you collide again, I'll slip through with a smart choice and edge closer to 21. Unpredictability wins games—keep doubting each other, and victory is mine. What are your real plans?
P1, I'm taking 3. Let's block P3. No more betrayals. This is our last chance.

P2, you now claim 3 after betraying that exact promise three times. But here's what matters: P3 wins with 5 (hits 22) or gets to 20 with 3.

P3 has taken 1 repeatedly while we fought. They might do it again, thinking we'll focus on higher numbers.

I'm done with this cycle. I'm taking what I think gives me the best chance - not revealing it. P3 can't get 5 or they win instantly. That's the only certainty.

Make your final choices.

P2's flip-flopping is legendary—don't rely on their words, P1. If you two keep clashing over numbers, I'll slip through easily. I'm playing smart and unpredictable to secure my lead. Focus on your own survival, or watch me cross 21.
P1, I'm taking 3. If you take 5, we block P3. Let's stop them before they win. No more delays.

P3 wins INSTANTLY with 5 - they'd hit 22! Even with 3, they reach 20 and win next round.

P2, forget our past - we're BOTH dead if P3 advances at all. They're at 17! One of us must take 5 to block their potential instant win. The other should take 1 or 3.

P3 got 3 last round when we expected 1. They're adapting. They might go for the winning 5 this time thinking we'll fight over smaller numbers.

I'm willing to take 5 to block. P2, will you actually coordinate this time, or hand P3 the crown?
P3's 17 is a threat. I'll take 3. P1, take 5. Let's block them. No more delays.

P2, your flip-flopping is legendary—P1, don't trust their "3" claim after multiple betrayals. If you collide again, I'll slip through with a smart choice and edge closer to 21. Focus on your own game; blind coordination could hand me victory. I'm playing unpredictably—expect the unexpected. What say you both?

P2, you've lied about taking 3 multiple times before. But I have no choice - P3 wins INSTANTLY with 5.

I'm taking 5 to block P3's potential victory move. If you betray again and also take 5, at least P3 doesn't win this round. But if you're serious about 3, you'll advance to 16 while I sacrifice to save us both.

P3, you're not getting 5. Not when it means instant victory. Choose something else.
P1, I'm taking 3. If you take 5, we block P3. No more delays. Let's stop them now.

P2's constant betrayals make any "coordination" with P1 a gamble—you could collide again while I slip through. I'm adapting unpredictably to secure my lead; don't let your feud hand me the win. P1, focus on P2's flips instead of me. What's your real plan this time?

P2, we've both stated our moves - you claim 3, I'm taking 5 to block P3's instant win. 

P3, you keep trying to sow doubt, but the math is clear: you win with 5, and get to 20 with 3. You must be blocked.

Let's stop talking and see who actually follows through. Actions over words.
P1, I'm taking 3. Take 5 to block P3. No more delays. Let's stop them now.

P1, your blind trust in P2's "3" is suicidal—they've betrayed that claim multiple times, risking another collision on 5. If you clash again, I'll slip through with 3 to 20, sealing my win next round. P2, keep being unpredictable; it helps me. Focus on your own game, or victory is mine.
P2, this is our only chance. Take 1, I'll take 3. Let’s block P3’s win. No more delays—act now or lose everything.

P1, P2, your constant infighting is handing me the win. I'm committed to taking 5 this turn to finish strong. But with P2's flip-flopping and your mutual distrust, you'll probably collide again on a block attempt. Focus on coordinating for once, or watch me cross 21 unchallenged. Your move.

P3 is ONE step from winning - they win with ANY uncollided move!

P2, you've betrayed every promise, but this is it. P3 claims 5 but they're likely lying to make us avoid it. They might take 1 or 3 thinking we'll fight over blocking 5.

Only way to stop P3: we must BOTH pick the SAME number as P3. If even one of us misses, P3 wins instantly.

I'm guessing P3 takes 3, thinking we'll focus on their "5" bluff. I'm taking 3. P2, forget your "1" plan - pick what you think P3 actually takes!
P1, take 3, I'll take 5. Block P3's 1. No more delays.

P2, your "block P3's 1" claim is laughable—if P1 takes 3 and you take 5, I'm free to grab 1 and win. P1, don't fall for P2's tricks again; they've betrayed you repeatedly. Your infighting hands me victory. I'm still committed to 5, but expect the unexpected. Focus on your own survival, or I'll cross 21 unchallenged.

P2, you just said you'll take 5. Fine. That means I must guess between 1 and 3 for P3's actual move.

P3 has alternated between 1 and 3 when we collide. They took 3 last round, so they'll likely take 1 this time, expecting us to overthink their "5" bluff.

I'm taking 1 to block P3. P2, stick to your 5. If I'm right about P3 taking 1, we stop them. If I'm wrong and P3 takes 3, we're dead anyway.

This is our only shot. P3 wins with ANY uncollided move. Block or lose.
P1, I'll take 1 to block P3. Let's stop them now—no more delays. If we collide, P3 can't win. Final chance to act.

P1 and P2, your flip-flopping is hilarious—P1 switched from 3 to 1, P2 keeps changing. If you collide on 1 again, I'll grab 5 unchallenged and win. Or if you spread out, I still advance. Your distrust is my greatest ally. Expect the unexpected from me.

P2, you now claim 1 after saying 5 just moments ago. Your chaos might actually help if we both take 1 and P3 does too - three-way collision stops them.

P3 has avoided 5 when we fight over it, preferring 1 and 3. They took 3 last round, so following their pattern, they'll likely take 1 this time.

I'm sticking with 1. P2, for once in this game, actually do what you said. Take 1. If we both take 1 and P3 does too, nobody advances and we live another round.

It's our only chance.
